children.name: drive
children.definition: verbdrove,drivenFORCE

children.name: bring
children.definition: verbbrought,broughtCAUSE
examples: _[ + two objects ]She's brought us so much happiness over the years.
_[ + -ing verb ]The explosion brought the whole building crashingto the ground.
_Several trees were broughtdown(= made to fall) by the storm.
_The closure of the factory brought povertytothe town (= resulted in it becoming poor) .
_Bring the waterUKto the boil/USto a boil(= make it start boiling) .
_She suddenly brought the interviewto an end.
_Her tragic story broughttears tomyeyes(= made me cry) .
_Whatwill the futurebring for these refugees?

children.name: to cause, result in or produce a state or condition
have
children.definition: verbhad,hadCAUSE

children.name: hold
children.definition: verbheld,heldMAKE HAPPEN

children.name: to cause sb/sth to be in a particular situation or condition
make
children.definition: /meɪk/  làm cho/làmnên/làm ra

children.name: make sb late/ill etc
examples: ▪ Hurry up - you’re going to make me late for work.
▪ Something I ate last night really made me sick.

children.name: make sth safe/interesting/dirty etc
examples: ▪ He could make things very difficult for us.
▪ Engineers have been working throughout the night to make the bridge safe.
▪ We gave the house a coat of paint to make it more attractive.

children.name: make it easy/impossible/necessary etc (for sb) to do sth
examples: ▪ The regulations should make it easier for patients to receive the treatment they need.
▪ The increased costs made it impossible to continue producing the computers in the U.S.

children.name: have
children.definition: to make sth be in a particular condition, especially so that it is ready to be used:làm cho

children.name: have sth ready/organized/prepared etc
examples: ▪ We’ll have your car ready by 3 o'clock.
▪ I’m going to have the roof fixed as soon as I can afford it.
▪ My parents had the little train all laid out under the tree on Christmas morning.

children.name: render
children.definition: formal to make sb/sth unable to do sth, work properly, cause any damage etc:làm cho

children.name: render sth useless/impossible/harmless etc
examples: ▪ Both runways have been rendered useless by enemy bombings.
▪ The angry exchange rendered future compromise impossible.

children.name: render sb unconscious/helpless etc
examples: ▪ Suddenly Packer struck a blow that rendered his victim unconscious.

children.name: plunge sth into
children.definition: plunge sb/sth into to cause sb/sth to suddenly be in a very bad situation:gây ra/khiến cho

children.name: plunge sb/sth into debt/war/depression etc
examples: The government’s uncontrolled spending has plunged the country into debt.
The growing hostility between the two parties is threatening to plunge the country into civil war.

children.name: put sb into sth
children.definition: put sb in/into sthđặt ai vào trình trạng

children.name: put sb in a difficult/awkward/impossible situation/positionto do something that causes someone difficulties, embarrassment etc:đặt ai vào thế khó khăn/bất tiện/không thể
examples: The minister’s comments have put the prime minister into a very awkward position.
I’m afraid I’ve been put into a rather embarrassing position.

children.name: breed
children.definition: verbbred,bredCAUSE

children.name: impliment
children.definition: implementverb

children.name: to put a plan or system into operation
examples: _The changes to the national health system will be implemented next year.

children.name: plant
children.definition: verbPUT
examples: [ T usually + adverb or preposition ]
to cause an idea or story to exist
_That incident planteddoubtsabout himinmy mind.
_Who planted theserumours?

children.name: see
children.definition: verbseeing,saw,seenMAKE CERTAIN

children.name: produce
children.definition: verbCAUSE

children.name: to cause a reaction or result
examples: _The prime minister's speech produced an angry response from the opposition.
_Her remarks produced an awkward silence.
_If used on delicate skin, this cream may produce a stinging sensation.

children.name: send
children.definition: verbsent,sentCAUSE TO HAPPEN
examples: _[ + adjective ]UKHis untidiness sends her crazy/mad/wild.
_[ + -ing verb ]The announcement of the fall in profits sent the company's share price plummeting(= caused it to go down a lot) .
_The draught from the fan sent papers flyingall over the room.

children.name: to cause someone or something to do a particular thing, or to cause something to happen
examples: _The explosion sent the crowdintoa panic.
_Watching the television always sends meto sleep.

children.name: fulfil
children.definition: -ll-,US usuallyfulfillverbMAKE HAPPEN

children.name: to do something that is expected, hoped for or promised or to cause it to happen
examples: _A school fails if it does not fulfil theneeds/requirementsof its pupils.
_At the age of 45, she finally fulfilled herambitionto run a marathon.
_Zoos fulfil an importantfunctionin the protection of rare species.
_He has failed to fulfil hisdutiesas a father.
_We're looking for a very specific sort of person and this woman seems to fulfil all of ourcriteria.
_So did the course fulfil all yourexpectations?
_We're suing our suppliers for failing to fulfil their contract.

children.name: spark
children.definition: nounCAUSE

children.name: put
children.definition: verbputting,put,putCONDITION

children.name: stir
children.definition: verb-rr-CAUSE EMOTION

children.name: realize
children.definition: ,UKusuallyrealiseverbACHIEVE
examples: [ T ] to achieve something you were hoping for
_Lots of money, a luxury house, a fast car - Danny had realized all his ambitions by the age of 25.
realization,C2UK usuallyrealisationnounACHIEVEMENT
[ U ] when you achieve something you planned to do or hoped for
_To win the Olympic gold medal was the realization of his life's dream.

children.name: to
children.definition: prepositionCAUSING

children.name: causing a particular feeling in a particular person
examples: _That's when I learned, to my horror, that she was coming here.

children.name: set
children.definition: verbsetting,set,setCONDITION

children.name: set
children.definition: verbsetting,set,setESTABLISH

children.name: stimulate
children.definition: verb

children.name: associate sth with sth
children.definition: associatesthwithsthphrasal verb

children.name: If problems or dangers are associated with a particular thing or action, they are caused by it
examples: _The cancer risks associated with smoking have been well documented.

children.name: to be the first or basic cause of sth
be at the root
children.definition: /bottom of  to be the basic cause of a problem or serious situation:là ngọn nguồn/gốc rễ
examples: ▪ Simple greed is at the root of most white-collar crime.
▪ At the bottom of the country’s economic problems is its overwhelming debt.

children.name: lie at the root/bottom of sth
examples: ▪ Difficulties with the company’s overseas subsidiaries lie at the root of last year’s losses.

children.name: underlying
children.definition: underlying cause/reason/factor etca cause, reason etc that is one of the most basic and important, but which is not easy to notice: cơ bản
examples: They were treating only the symptoms of the disease rather than its underlying cause.
Climate and geography are the underlying reasons for the region’s low level of economic development.

children.name: to believe that sth is caused by a particular thing
put sth down to
children.definition: put something down to/ˌpʊt something ˈdaʊn tuː/  to explain a situation, event, or behaviour by saying that it is the result of sth else: g
examples: ▪ Charlie’s been drinking a lot lately, which I put down to stress at work.
▪ Authorities put the acts of vandalism down to ‘festive high spirits’ after the team’s victory.
▪ Her restlessness was put down to excitement, and nobody realised she was seriously ill.

children.name: attribute sth to
children.definition: formal to explain a situation or fact by saying that it is the result of sth else:là do/nhờ
examples: ▪ Over 1,000 deaths a year can be attributed to drunk driving.
▪ The low crop yields are attributed to changes in climate.
▪ The management attributed the success of the company to the new Marketing Director.

children.name: to be one of the causes of sth
play a part
children.definition: if something plays a part in something, it is one of several things that makes it happen or be successful: đóng vai trò
examples: ▪ Many cases of breast cancer have genetic causes, but environmental substances may also play a part.

children.name: play a part in
examples: ▪ It is not yet known if weather conditions played a part in the accident.
▪ The genius of the two designers has played a big part in the company’s recent success.

children.name: contribute to
children.definition: /kənˈtrɪbjuːt tuːǁ-bjət-/  if something contributes to a situation or event, it is one of the things that make it happen:góp phần làm cho
examples: ▪ An increase in the price of drugs has contributed to the rising cost of medical care.Sự gia tăng giá thuốc đã góp phần làm tăng chi phí chăm sóc y tế
▪ It is thought that the pilot’s negligence may have contributed to the disaster.Người ta cho rằng là do sự sơ suất của phi công đã gây ra tai nạn

children.name: contributory
children.definition: /kənˈtrɪbjɑtəriǁ-tɔːri/ formalcontributory cause/factor one of several causes of something that happens, but not the main cause:có đóng góp/nguyên nhân
examples: ▪ Malnutrition was considered to have been a contributory cause of death.Sự suy dinh dưỡng được coi là nguyên nhân gây tử vong
▪ Alcohol is a contributory factor in at least 50% of the violent crimes reported.Rượu là một yếu tố góp phần ít nhất 50% cho các tội phạm bạo lực

children.name: to make sth bad suddenly happen
set off
children.definition: if sb/sth sets off a fight, war etc, it makes it start happening:bắt đầu, mở đầu
examples: The army’s invasion set off a major international crisis.
Nobody knows what set the riot off.

children.name: trigger
children.definition: /sparkC2  if a small action or event triggers or sparks serious trouble or changes, it causes them to happen very quickly:kích hoạt (gây ra điều gì)
examples: Even the smallest diplomatic incident can trigger a major international conflict.
The assassination of Archduke Francis Ferdinand sparked the First World War.

children.name: trigger/spark off sth
examples: Riots, sparked off by the arrest of seven student leaders, have spread to other universities.

children.name: precipitate
children.definition: formal to make sth serious happen, especially more quickly than was expected:làm xảy ra (nhanh hơn dự kiến)
examples: The 1929 stock market crash precipitated the collapse of the American banking system.
Both countries claimed the same area, precipitating a border war.

children.name: make
children.definition: sth do sth  tocausesthsto happen.Makeis less formal thancause, and is the usual word to use in everyday English :khiến, làm cho
examples: I wish you wouldn’t slam the door. It makes the floor shake.
Accidents don’t always just happen - people can make them happen.
Gravity is the force that makes the planets move around the sun.

children.name: cause
children.definition: to make something happen, especially something unpleasant:gây ra
examples: Heavy traffic is causing delays on the freeway.
The fire caused £15,000 worth of damage.

children.name: cause a problem
examples: The heavy rain has been causing serious problems on the roads.

children.name: cause trouble
examples: I decided not to complain because I didn’t want to cause trouble.

children.name: cause damage
examples: A fire had broken out and caused severe damage to the roof.

children.name: cause
children.definition: a
examples: diseaseScientists are trying to find out what causes the disease.

children.name: cause injury
examples: Rugby is one of the sports that are most likely to cause injury.

children.name: cause pain
examples: The infection can cause severe pain.

children.name: cause death
examples: The famine caused the death of up to 400,000 people.

children.name: cause
children.definition: a
examples: delayBad weather caused delays at many airports.

children.name: cause chaos/disruption
examples: Floods caused chaos across much of the country.

children.name: cause concern/alarm
examples: Environmental issues are causing widespread concern.

children.name: cause confusion
examples: Teachers say the reforms will cause confusion in schools.

children.name: cause offence/embarrassment
children.definition: offend/embarrass someone
examples: How can I refuse the invitation without causing offence?

children.name: cause sth for sb
examples: The oil spill is causing problems for coastal fisheries.

children.name: cause concern/uncertainty/embarrassment etc
examples: The policy changes have caused great uncertainty for the workforce.
I’m sorry if Icausedanyconfusion.

children.name: cause sb trouble/problems etc
examples: You’ve caused us all a lot of unnecessary worry.
Sorry, I didn’t mean tocause offence(= offend you ).

children.name: cause sth to do sth
examples: The power failure caused the whole computer system to shut down.
cause an accident75% of accidents are caused by speeding.

children.name: be the cause
children.definition: to be the particular reason for a problem or difficulty:là nguyên nhân
examples: ▪ After a long investigation into the fire, faulty wiring was found to be the cause.

children.name: be the cause of
examples: ▪ It’s too early to say whether this virus is actually the cause of the disease.
▪ An explosion on board appears to be the cause of the crash.

children.name: be the leading/main cause of sth
examples: ▪ The study showed that drug use is the leading cause of crime and violence.

children.name: be responsible
children.definition: to be the person or thing that causes something bad to happen, for example a mistake, a problem, or a serious accident:chịu trách nhiệm
examples: ▪ The number of workplace accidents is increasing, but it is not clear who or what is responsible.

children.name: be responsible for
examples: ▪ Heart disease was responsible for most of the deaths.
▪ He was clearly responsible for the deaths and must be punished.

children.name: be largely/mainly responsible for sth
examples: ▪ Inflation was largely responsible for the economic crisis.

children.name: result in sth
children.definition: if an action or event results in something, it makes something happen:dẫn tới/ gây ra
examples: ▪ Workers fear that the company’s reorganization will result in layoffs.
▪ Months of secret talks with the rebels finally resulted in the release of the hostages.
▪ If left untreated, the condition will eventually result in blindness.

children.name: bring about
children.definition: to make sth happen, especially a change or an improved situation:dẫn đến, đưa ra, mang đến
examples: ▪ The President will support any efforts to bring about a ceasefire.
▪ Education is the best method of bringing about economic development.
▪ A lot of hard work by ordinary citizens eventually brought the changes about.

children.name: give rise to
children.definition: formal if a situation, event, or action gives rise to a particular feeling, situation etc, it starts the process that makes it happen:gây ra, làm tăng lên
examples: The canal project gave rise to a malaria epidemic in the region.
The President’s frequent cancellations have given rise to concerns about his health.

children.name: lead to sth
children.definition: to start a process that finally makes sth happen:dẫn đến/ gây ra
examples: His research eventually led to the development of a vaccine.
The new regulations should lead to an improvement in our water supply.
The bank has offered a reward for information leading to the arrest of the robbers.

children.name: create U
children.definition: create to make a particular condition that did not exist at all suddenly exist:tạo ra
examples: ▪ The white walls and mirrors helped to create an illusion of space.
▪ Margot’s outburst created an unpleasant atmosphere and most of the guests left early.
▪ The end of the cold war helped create a situation in which more countries than ever have access to nuclear weapons.

children.name: make for
children.definition: if sth makes for a particular situation, it makes it easier or more likely for that situation to exist:làm cho/làm ra
examples: The stormy weather made for a very bumpy landing.
Delicious food and wonderful company made for a very enjoyable evening.

children.name: sth that makes sth else happen
cause
children.definition: a person, event, or thing that makes something happen →effect:nguyên nhân
examples: Doctors cannot find a cure for the illness until they have identified the cause.

children.name: a common cause of sth
examples: Alcohol is the most common cause of road accidents.

children.name: the main/primary cause of something
examples: Smoking is the main cause of lung disease.

children.name: a major/leading cause of something
examples: In this country, debt is a major cause of homelessness.|Drug abuse is the leading cause of crime and violence.

children.name: a direct/indirect cause
examples: Government policies are the direct cause of the problems facing the economy.

children.name: the root cause
children.definition: the most basic cause
examples: People often deal with the symptoms rather than the root cause of a problem.

children.name: the fundamental/underlying cause
children.definition: the root cause
examples: The underlying cause of insomnia is often anxiety.

children.name: the probable/likely cause
examples: The probable cause of the fire was faulty wiring.

children.name: discover/find the cause
examples: An investigation has failed to discover the cause of the epidemic.

children.name: determine/establish/identify the cause
children.definition: discover definitely what it is
examples: A team of experts is at the scene of the accident, trying to determine the cause.

children.name: investigate the cause
examples: Police are still investigating the cause of the fire.

children.name: the cause of death
examples: A snake bite was the cause of death.

children.name: die of/from natural causes
children.definition: die of illness, old age etc, not because of an accident or crime
examples: He died from natural causes, believed to be a heart attack.

children.name: cause and effect
children.definition: the idea that one thing directly causes another
examples: What happened was simply a question of cause and effect.

children.name: cause of
examples: Breast cancer is the leading cause of death for American women in their 40s.
It’s our job to establish the cause of the fire.
►Do not say ‘the cause for something’. Saythe cause of something.

children.name: factor
children.definition: /ˈfæktəʳ/  one of several causes of a situation or condition:yếu tố
examples: ▪ The price of insurance depends on several factors, including the age of the car.Giá bảo hiểm phụ thuộc vào nhiều yếu tố, bao gồm cả tuổi thọ của xe
factor in: yếu tố trong cái gì/điều gì
▪ His girlfriend lives in London and I’m sure that was a factor in his decision to move there.Bạn gái của anh ta sống ở luân đôn và tôi chắc chắn rằng đó chính là yếu tố khiến anh ta di chuyển tới đó
key factorvery important factor:yếu tố quan trọng/ yếu tố then chốt
▪ Money will be the key factor when we decide to buy a new house.Tiền bạc là yếu tố then chốt khi chúng ta quyết định mua nhà mới
deciding/determining factorthe thing that finally makes something happen:yếu tố quyết định
▪ Race should never be a deciding factor in a hiring decision.Chủng tộc không bao giờ là yếu tố quyết định trong quyết định tuyển dụng một ai.

children.name: reason
children.definition: /ˈriːzən/  the thing or one of the things that makes you decide to do something or makes something happen:nguyên nhân
examples: ▪ ‘Why are you helping her?’ ‘She asked me to. That’s the only reason.’"Tại sao lại giúp cô ta? "cô ấy muốn tôi giúp. đó là lý do duy nhất"
▪ The main reason she quit is that she was not being paid enough.lí do chính mà cô ấy nghỉ việc là vì cô ấy không được trả đủ lương
reason for/behind: nguyên nhân cho/đằng sau cái gì/điều gì
▪ Can anyone explain the reason for the delay?Ai đó có thể giải thích lí do cho sự chậm trễ này không?
▪ There were two reasons behind the company’s failure.Có 2 lí do đằng sau sự thất bại của công ty
reason why/(that): lí do tại sao
▪ The reason why the economy is growing more slowly is a lack of workers.Lí do tại sao mà nền kinh tế đang tăng trưởng chậm là vì sự thiếu nhân công
reason to do something: lí do để làm điều gì
▪ There’s no reason to doubt what she says.Không có lí do gì để nghi ngờ những điều cô ấy nói

children.name: origins
children.definition: /ˈɒrɪdʒənz, ˈɒrədʒənzǁˈɔː-, ˈɑː-/  the first causes from which a situation, condition etc has developed:Nguồn gốc
examples: origins of nguồn gốc của
▪ The origins of the crisis were very complex.Nguồn gốc gây ra cuộc khủng hoảng này rất phức tạp
▪ Other cultures’ beliefs about the origins of disease often differ from our own.Các niềm tin của các nền văn hóa khác về nguồn gốc của bệnh thì thì thường khác so với chúng ta.
have origins in: có nguồn gốc từ

▪ Many of our attitudes to the issue of race have their origins in the colonialism of days gone by.Nhiều thái độ của chúng ta đối với vấn đề chủng tộc có nguồn gốc từ chủ nghĩa thực dân của ngày trước

children.name: root
children.definition: /ruːt/  the main or most important cause of a situation or condition:nguồn gốc, gốc rễ
examples: root of: nguồn gốc của
▪ The roots of the wars in the Balkans go back hundreds of years.Nguồn gốc của chiến tranh ở Balkans thuộc về khoảng vài trăm năm trước
get to the root of somethingdiscover the most important cause:Tìm ra nguyên nhân/gốc rễ của cái gì/điều gì
▪ We need to get to the root of the problem.Chúng ta cần tìm ra căn nguyên của vấn đề

children.name: stimulus
children.definition: /ˈstɪmjɑləs/  an event, action, or situation that helps a process to develop more quickly:sự khích lệ/ kích thích
examples: ▪ The appointment of a new director gave the project immediate stimulus.Việc bổ nhiệm một giám đốc mới đã khích lệ dự án ngay lập tức
stimulus to: khích lệ/kích thích đối với
▪ The surge in new housing construction ought to provide a stimulus to the economy.Đợt sóng dâng lên trong công trình xây dựng nhà của có thể kích thích phát triển kinh tế

children.name: impetus
children.definition: /ˈɪmpɪtəs, ˈɪmpətəs/  an event, action, or situation that helps something to develop more quickly: sự thúc đẩy/động lực
examples: impetus for/behind
▪ The impetus for change in the industry was provided by a new management team.Động lực thúc đẩy sự thay đổi trong nghành công nghiệp được đưa ra bởi đội ngũ quản lí mới
▪ Press criticism has been the main impetus behind the government reforms.Chỉ trích từ báo chí từ lâu đã là động lực chính cho những cải cách từ chính phủ
give impetus to sth
▪ The Surgeon General’s speech will give new impetus to the anti-smoking campaign.Bài phát biểu của Bác si Surgeon sẽ tạo động lực cho chiến dịch chống hút thuốc.

children.name: to deliberately cause trouble, arguments etc
incite
children.definition: formal to deliberately encourage people to cause trouble, fight, argue etc:kích động/xúi giục/khuyến khích
examples: ▪ Four men were arrested for inciting the riot.
incitement[U]
▪ By publishing the book they were guilty of incitement to racial hatred.

children.name: incite sb to sth
examples: ▪ She was charged with inciting the crowd to violence.

children.name: incite sb to do sth
examples: ▪ Tribal leaders are accused of inciting their followers to attack rival tribes.

children.name: provoke
children.definition: if sth provokes an angry situation or a reaction, they cause it, usually deliberately: kích động/xúi giục
examples: ▪ The new laws have provoked violent demonstrations in some towns.
▪ The ambassador’s offensive remarks provoked widespread criticism.

children.name: provoke sb to sth
examples: ▪ The judge ruled that Becker provoked her husband to attack her so she could shoot him.

children.name: stir up
children.definition: to deliberately try to cause arguments, fighting etc between people: khuấy động, kích động, gây ra
examples: ▪ I hope you’re not trying to stir up trouble.
▪ His series of articles on party leaders has stirred up a great deal of public controversy.
▪ He was accused of trying to stir rebellion up among the peasants.
